title: The Nature and Experience of Entrepreneurial Passion
keywords: entrepreneurial passion, role identity, cognitive coherence, behavioral mechanisms, emotional energy
abstract: Entrepreneurial passion plays a crucial role in entrepreneurship but lacks theoretical understanding. This paper builds on existing fragmented work to conceptualize entrepreneurial passion associated with key role identities and theorizes the mechanisms that provide coherence to goal-directed cognitions and behaviors during the pursuit of entrepreneurial effectiveness.
original_filename: 17 - Cardon et al. 2009.pdf

title: How Do Feelings Influence Effort? An Empirical Study of Entrepreneurs’ Affect and Venture Effort
keywords: entrepreneurial affect, affect, venture effort, temporal focus, affect-as-information
abstract: To understand how feelings influence the effort of entrepreneurs, the authors used experience sampling methodology with 46 entrepreneurs over 24 days. The study found that negative affect directly predicts immediate venture effort, while positive affect predicts future-oriented venture effort through future temporal focus.
original_filename: 18 - Foo et al. 2009.pdf

title: Competing Models of Entrepreneurial Intentions
keywords: Entrepreneurial Intentions, Theory of Planned Behavior, Model Comparison, Predictive Validity, Entrepreneurship
abstract: This study compares Ajzen's theory of planned behavior (TPB) and Shapero’s model of the entrepreneurial event (SEE) to predict entrepreneurial intentions. The research finds that intentions are the single best predictor of any planned behavior, including entrepreneurship, emphasizing the importance of understanding the antecedents of intentions for better prediction.
original_filename: 19 - Krueger et al. 2000.pdf

title: Survival of the Fittest? Entrepreneurial Human Capital and the Persistence of Underperforming Firms
keywords: entrepreneurial human capital, organizational survival, economic performance, threshold model, new venture survival
abstract: This model explains why some firms survive while others with equal economic performance do not. It argues that organizational survival depends on a firm's own threshold of performance, which is influenced by the entrepreneur's human capital characteristics such as alternative employment opportunities, psychic income from entrepreneurship, and cost of switching to other occupations. The findings suggest that firms with low thresholds may choose to continue or survive despite comparatively low performance.
original_filename: 20 - Gimeno et al. 1997.pdf

title: VENTURING FOR OTHERS WITH HEART AND HEAD: HOW COMPASSION ENCOURAGES SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP
keywords: Social Entrepreneurship, Compassion, Prosocial Motivation, Integrative Thinking, Commitment
abstract: Social entrepreneurship has emerged as a promising organizational form using market-based methods to address social issues. This paper builds a model of three mechanisms (integrative thinking, prosocial cost-benefit analysis, and commitment to alleviating others' suffering) that transform compassion into social entrepreneurship, identifying the institutional conditions under which these mechanisms are most likely to occur.
original_filename: 21 - Miller et al. 2012.pdf

title: Entrepreneurial Exits and Innovation
keywords: entrepreneurialexits, innovation, informationconfidentiality
abstract: This article examines how initial public offerings (IPOs) and acquisitions affect entrepreneurial innovation as measured by patent counts and forward patent citations. Using a firm-year panel dataset of venture capital-backed biotechnology firms founded between 1980 and 2000, the study finds that innovation quality is highest under private ownership and lowest under public ownership, with acquisition intermediate between the two.
original_filename: Aggarwal, V. A., & Hsu, D. H. (2014). Entrepreneurial exit and innovation.pdf

title: Exploitation, Exploration, and Process Management: The Productivity Dilemma Revisited
keywords: process management, exploitation, exploration, organizational adaptation, dynamic capabilities
abstract: This paper develops a contingency view of process management's influence on technological innovation and organizational adaptation. It argues that while process management activities are beneficial in stable contexts, they are inconsistent with significant innovation and change. The authors propose that ambidextrous organizational forms can buffer exploitative and exploratory activities to enable coexistence.
original_filename: Benner, M. J., & Tushman, M. L. (2003). Exploitation, exploration, and process management- The productivity dilemma revisited. Academy of Management Review.pdf

title: Does Going Public Affect Innovation?
keywords: Innovation, IPO, Public Firms, Patent Metrics, Human Capital
abstract: This paper investigates the effects of going public on innovation by comparing the innovation activity of firms that go public with those that withdraw their IPO filing. Using patent-based metrics, it finds that while the quality of internal innovation declines post-IPO, public firms attract new human capital and acquire external innovation.
original_filename: Bernstein, S. (2015). Does going public affect innovation.pdf

title: Why the Lean Start-Up Changes Everything
keywords: lean start-up, entrepreneurship, business plan, customer feedback, experimentation
abstract: Launching a new enterprise has traditionally been a hit-or-miss proposition with high failure rates. However, the "lean start-up" methodology, which emphasizes experimentation over planning and customer feedback over intuition, is changing this landscape by making entrepreneurship less risky. This approach could ignite a new entrepreneurial economy.
original_filename: Blank 2013 Why the lean startup changes everything.pdf

title: The Art of Continuous Change: Linking Complexity Theory and Time-Paced Evolution in Relentlessly Shifting Organizations
keywords: complexity theory, time-paced evolution, organizational change, multiple-product innovation, semistructures
abstract: This inductive study examines how organizations engage in continuous change through multiple-product innovation. Successful firms blend limited structure with extensive communication to create improvisation, rely on a variety of low-cost probes into the future, and link present and future through rhythmic transition processes. The research challenges the punctuated equilibrium model by focusing on the importance of continuous incremental changes rather than radical ones.
original_filename: Brown, S. L., & Eisenhardt, K. M. (1997). The art of continuous change- Linking complexity theory and time-paced evolution in relentlessly shifting organizations.pdf

title: Can You Gig It? An Empirical Examination of the Gig Economy and Entrepreneurial Activity
keywords: gig economy, entrepreneurial activity, employment, stability, flexibility
abstract: We examine how the entry of gig-economy platforms influences local entrepreneurial activity. On one hand, such platforms may reduce entrepreneurial activity by offering stable employment for the unemployed and underemployed. On the other hand, they may enable entrepreneurial activity by offering work flexibility that allows the entrepreneur to redeploy resources strategically in pursuit of an nascent venture. To resolve this tension, we examine the entry of the ridesharing platform UberX into local areas.
original_filename: Burtch, G., Carnahan, S., & Greenwood, B. N. (2018). Can you gig it- An empirical examination of the gig economy and entrepreneurial activity.pdf

title: WHO LEAVES, WHERE TO, AND WHY WORRY? EMPLOYEE MOBILITY, ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND EFFECTS ON SOURCE FIRM PERFORMANCE
keywords: entrepreneurship, strategic human capital, employee mobility, complementary assets, professional service firms
abstract: We theorize that the value provided by a firm’s complementary assets has important implications for the exit decisions of employees and their subsequent effects on the firm's performance. Using linked employee-employer data from the U.S. Census Bureau on legal services, we find that higher-earning employees are less likely to leave but if they do, are more likely to create a new venture than join another firm. Employee entrepreneurship has a larger adverse impact on source firm performance than moves to established firms.
original_filename: Campbell, B. A., Ganco, M., Franco, A. M., & Agarwal, R. (2012). Who leaves, where to, and why worry Employee mobility, entrepreneurship, and effects on source firm performance.pdf

title: A Scienti c Approach to Entrepreneurial Decision Making:
keywords: entrepreneurship, decisionmaking, scientificmethod, startup, randomizedcontroltrial
abstract: This paper develops a framework for exploring the implications of a more scientific approach to entrepreneurial decision making. The study includes 116 Italian startups and finds that entrepreneurs who behave like scientists perform better, are more likely to pivot to a different idea, and are not more likely to drop out than the control group in the early stages of the startup.
original_filename: Camuffo, Cordova, Gambardella, & Spina MS 2020 A scientific approach to entrepreneurial decision making - Evidence from a randomized control trial.pdf

title: Customer power, strategic investment, and the failure of leading firms
keywords: innovation, resource allocation, strategy change, technological change, failure
abstract: We present a model based on a study of the world disk drive industry that links theories of resource dependence and allocation. Established firms led in developing technologies addressing existing customers' needs but failed to invest in simpler technologies for emerging markets due to lack of customer demand, ultimately losing their market position as new entrants capitalized on these technologies.
original_filename: Chistensen, Bower, 1996 Customer power, strategic investment, and the failure of leading firms.pdf

title: What Is a Patent Worth? Evidence from the U.S. Patent “Lottery”
keywords: patents, startups, innovation, employment growth, sales growth
abstract: We provide evidence on the value of patents to startups by leveraging the quasi-random assignment of applications to examiners with different propensities to grant patents. Startups that win the patent "lottery" by drawing lenient examiners have, on average, 55% higher employment growth and 80% higher sales growth five years later.
original_filename: Farre‐Mensa, J., Hegde, D., & Ljungqvist, A. (2020). What is a patent worth-Evidence from the US patent “lottery”.pdf

title: The Theory-Based View: Economic Actors as Theorists
keywords: strategy, cognition, perception, theory for the firm, governance
abstract: This paper outlines the theory-based view of strategy and markets, arguing that novel or "great" strategies come from theories. Entrepreneurs and managers originate theories and hypotheses about their activities, assets to buy, and value creation methods. A firm's strategy then represents a unique, firm-specific point of view—a set of beliefs and a theory about problem-solving and the organization and governance of value creation.
original_filename: Felin & Zenger SS 2017 The theory-based view - Economic actors as theorists.pdf

title: Theory-Based Decisions: Foundations and Introduction
keywords: theory-based view, decision making, strategy, entrepreneurship, causal reasoning, theories
abstract: Theories are foundational for decision making. We argue that decision makers should develop their own theories using the scientific method to problem solve and generate new data and value. This paper introduces the theory-based view (TBV) and its implications for key theories within strategy and economics, along with highlighting research opportunities.
original_filename: Felin, Gambardella, & Zenger SS 2024 Theory-based decisions - Foundations and introduction.pdf

title: A Scientific Method for Startups
keywords: entrepreneurship theory, lean startup, theory-based view, scientific method, startups
abstract: Recent scholarship has sought to develop a “scientific method” for startups by contrasting the lean startup approach with the theory-based view. While both approaches share an agenda for a normative and scientific approach, they differ in their underlying theoretical mechanisms and practical prescriptions, emphasizing different aspects such as bounded rationality versus generative rationality. The paper highlights these differences and discusses opportunities for partial reconciliation and empirical comparison.
original_filename: Felin, Gambardella, Novelli, & Zenger JOM 2024 A scientific method for startups.pdf

title: The Financing of Innovation
keywords: R&D, innovation, financing, liquidity constraints, venture capital
abstract: Evidence on the “funding gap” for innovation is surveyed. The focus is on financial market reasons for underinvestment in innovation that persist even in the absence of externality-induced underinvestment. The conclusions are that small and new innovative firms experience high costs of capital, while evidence for high costs of R&D capital for large firms is mixed; further study of governmental seed capital and subsidy programs using quasi-experimental methods is warranted.
original_filename: Hall, B. H. (2005). The financing of innovation. The Handbook of Technology and Innovation Management, 409-430..pdf

title: Structural Inertia and Organizational Change
keywords: Structural Inertia, Organizational Change, Population Ecology, Selection Processes, Evolutionary Theory
abstract: Theory and research on organization-environment relations from a population ecology perspective have been based on the assumption that inertial pressures on structure are strong. This paper attempts to clarify the meaning of structural inertia and to derive propositions about structural inertia from an explicit evolutionary model.
original_filename: Hannan, Freeman, 1984, Structural Inertia and Organizational Change.pdf

title: Core capabilities and core rigidities: A paradox in managing new product development
keywords: Core capabilities, innovation, new product development, project management, organizational change
abstract: This paper examines the nature of a firm's core capabilities, focusing on their interaction with new product and process development projects. It explores two new concepts about core capabilities—values as an overlooked but critical dimension—and how traditional core capabilities can inhibit innovation, creating a paradox for managers to navigate.
original_filename: Leonard‐Barton,1992 - Core capabilities and core rigidities  A paradox in managing new product development.pdf

title: Mobility, Skills, and the Michigan Non-Compete Experiment
keywords: labor, statistics, design of experiments, organizational studies, personnel
abstract: This paper explores a legal constraint on employee mobility—employee non-compete agreements—by exploiting Michigan’s 1985 reversal of its non-compete enforcement policy as a natural experiment. Using a differences-in-differences approach, it finds that enforcing non-competes indeed attenuates mobility, more so for inventors with firm-specific skills and those specializing in narrow technical fields.
original_filename: Marx, M., Strumsky, D., & Fleming, L. (2009). Mobility, skills, and the Michigan non-compete experiment..pdf

title: Firm boundaries matter: Evidence from conglomerates and R&D activity
keywords: Conglomerates, Theory of firm, Innovation, R&D, Mergers, Incentives
abstract: This paper examines the impact of the conglomerate form on the scale and novelty of corporate Research and Development (R&D) activity. I exploit a quasi-experiment involving failed mergers to generate exogenous variation in acquisition outcomes, revealing that firms acquired in diversifying mergers produce both fewer innovations and less-novel innovations.
original_filename: Seru, A. (2014). Firm boundaries matter- Evidence from conglomerates and R&D activity..pdf

title: Prior Knowledge and the Discovery of Entrepreneurial Opportunities
keywords: entrepreneurship, opportunity discovery, prior knowledge, technological innovation, case studies
abstract: This article argues that opportunity discovery is a function of the distribution of information in society. Drawing on Austrian economics, it demonstrates through in-depth case studies that entrepreneurs discover opportunities related to the information they already possess, suggesting that this process is far from trivial.
original_filename: Shane, S. (2000). Prior knowledge and the discovery of entrepreneurial opportunities.pdf

title: Screening Spinouts? How Noncompete Enforceability Affects the Creation, Growth, and Survival of New Firms
keywords: noncompete covenants, spinouts, firm creation, growth, survival
abstract: This paper examines how the enforceability of noncompete covenants affects the creation, growth, and survival of spinouts and other new entrants. Greater enforceability is associated with fewer within-industry spinouts (WSOs) but WSOs that are created tend to start larger, are founded by higher-earners, and are more likely to survive their initial years.
original_filename: Starr, E., Balasubramanian, N., & Sakakibara, M. (2018). Screening spinouts-How noncompete enforceability affects the creation, growth, and survival of new firms..pdf

title: Entrepreneurs as pragmatist scientists: A pragmatist alternative to the creation-discovery debate
keywords: Entrepreneurs, Pragmatism, Scientists, Discovery, Creation, Problem-solving
abstract: The paper argues that entrepreneurs should be seen not just as scientists seeking to understand their world but also as engineers, designers, and artists who act to create value. It challenges the traditional creation-discovery debate by placing entrepreneurship within a pragmatic framework where all humans, including entrepreneurs, behave like scientists in addressing problems.
original_filename: Zellweger & Zenger AMR 2022 Entrepreneurs as scientists - A pragmatist alternative to the creation-discovery debate.pdf

title: Entrepreneurs as scientists: A pragmatist approach to producing value out of uncertainty
keywords: entrepreneurship, pragmatism, uncertainty, scientific approach, value creation
abstract: Building on pragmatism, the paper advances an entrepreneur-as-scientist perspective where entrepreneurs engage in causally inferential actions by forming beliefs, testing them, and responding to feedback. However, this process comes with doubts about product-market fit, feedback validity, and over- or under-fitting responses.
original_filename: Zellweger & Zenger AMR 2023 Entrepreneurs as scientists - A pragmatist approach to producing value out of uncertainty.pdf
